title: From a painting to a viral photo, a fight for Ukraine's history
summary: The French photographer Emeric Lhuisse staged a new version of a painting by 19th-century Ukrainian artist Ilya Repin, a famous work that is claimed by both Russia and Ukraine.

title: Israel-Hamas war: The five weeks of back-channel talks that led to a truce
summary: Fifty women and children held by Hamas in Gaza will be released in exchange for 150 Palestinian prisoners and a limited truce.

title: Anti-Islam populist Geert Wilders wins Dutch election
summary: Wilders' Freedom Party won 35 seats in parliament on Wednesday, a landslide according to the Ipsos exit poll. If confirmed, the populist's victory will be viewed with trepidation in Brussels: his party promised a referendum on Dutch membership of the European Union.

title: French MEPs claim victory as European Parliament votes not to ban Camembert box
summary: A European proposal on packaging waste management led to a sudden flurry of activity by French MEPs, with lawmakers ranging from liberals to the far-right voting to save the traditional wooden camembert box.

title: Venezuela accuses Peru of 'kidnapping' its football team
summary: Amidst a wild night of violent clashes between Lima police, Venezuelan players and football fans, Caracas has alleged that Lima prevented 'the plane bringing the team back from refueling.'

title: 'Moscow's tone is triumphalist, and yet, the war amplifies existing handicaps of Russia's economy'
summary: While Vladimir Putin tries to show Russia at its best, the war against Ukraine has ultimately absorbed all the country's resources and lifeblood, writes Le Monde columnist Jean-Michel Bezat.

title: 2 dead after vehicle explodes at Rainbow Bridge border crossing in Niagara Falls
summary: The vehicle speeding toward a US-Canada bridge from the American side crashed at a checkpoint on Wednesday, prompting the closing of four border crossings in the area. New York Governor Kathy Hochul said there was 'no indication of a terrorist attack'.

title: Backed by Microsoft, Sam Altman returns as OpenAI CEO
summary: The internal drama at the company that created ChatGPT has taken another twist: Sacked on Friday, the co-founder is back and an interim board of directors has been appointed.

title: French senator, suspected of drugging MP, dropped by political allies
summary: While in previous cases politicians said the 'presumption of innocence' prevailed, Senator Joël Guerriau was immediately suspended by his own party, Horizons, and then asked to 'step aside' by Sénat President Gérard Larcher.

title: Guns N' Roses frontman Axl Rose accused of sexual assault
summary: Rose was accused of sexually assaulting Sheila Kennedy in 1989, 'pursuant to the N.Y. Adult Survivors Act,' a New York law allowing sexual abuse victims to file suits past the statute of limitations, which expires Thursday.

title: UK unveils sweeping tax cuts in budget ahead of election
summary: British Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt delivered an autumn statement on Wednesday hoping to woo voters ahead of the 2024 general election.

title: France refuses to pay up for failing to meet renewable energy targets
summary: In 2009, the government pledged to achieve a share of 23% renewables (wind, solar, hydro) in its gross final energy consumption by 2020. But it only reached 20.7% in 2022.

title: EU parliament scraps proposal to halve pesticide use
summary: In a 299-to-207 vote, the recommendation was refused, reflecting right-wing parties' desires to win votes from farmers before the EU elections in June.

title: Palestinian ambassador to France Hala Abou Hassira has lost 60 relatives to bombings
summary: The Palestinian Authority's representative in France is from Gaza. As she campaigns for the release of Israeli hostages and Palestinian prisoners, she watches in despair as the Israeli bombings raze her hometown.

title: 'The challenger may have changed, but the world's leading superpower is still on top'
summary: In three decades, China has replaced Russia in the rivalry between the United States and the USSR. The mid-November summit between Joe Biden and Xi Jinping showed that American power remains unchallenged, writes Le Monde columnist Sylvie Kauffmann.

title: Scientists finally identify protein responsible for initiating ovarian development in embryo
summary: More than 30 years after the discovery of the genetic signal responsible for embryonic masculinization, a French team has pinpointed the subtle mechanism that triggers ovarian growth.

title: More than two months after the earthquake in Morocco: 'We don't know how we're going to get through the winter in these tents'
summary: As temperatures continue to fall, not all disaster victims have received the emergency aid promised by the Moroccan government. Many are living in precarious conditions.

title: Sweden to impose 'honorable lifestyle' as residency condition
summary: On Tuesday, the ruling coalition of right-wing and far-right parties announced its intention to expel foreign citizens who fail to respect the kingdom's 'fundamental values.'

title: The five surprises revealed by the James Webb telescope
summary: After a first annual cycle of observations of the Universe's youth, the spectacular images sent back by the space telescope have already upset many astrophysicists' predictions. Everything in the cosmos happened earlier and faster than expected.

title: In Russia, Yegor Balazeikin, a 17-year-old ’terrorist,’ sentenced to six years in prison
summary: The young man, a high school student, was found guilty by a military court of attacking recruitment offices. 'My conscience will judge me,' he said at the hearing.

title: North Korea suspends military accord with South after satellite launch
summary: Pyongyang said Wednesday it was suspending a half-decade-old accord reached with Seoul to reduce military tensions, the latest retaliatory fallout over North Korea's spy satellite launch. The South had decided earlier to partially suspend the 2018 deal.

title: South Korea denounces an 'act of provocation' after North Korea launches a military spy satellite
summary: Seoul retaliated to this launch by suspending a 2018 military agreement with the North Korean regime, designed to limit border tensions between the two countries. On Thursday, the North said it was ripping up the agreement entirely.

title: 'It's like putting a camera in every house': WhatsApp's boss defends message encryption in the face of a European bill
summary: The European Union is currently working on a regulation to combat child pornography: in certain versions of the bill, messaging services would be obliged to inspect all messages sent by their users.

title: China is rediscovering the painter Zao Wou-ki
summary: 200 works by this artist who lived in France from 1948 until his death in 2013 are on display at the Chinese Academy of Arts in Hangzhou, where he studied and taught.

title: French energy minister: Necessary transition 'is on a scale comparable to the first industrial revolution'
summary: French Energy Transition Minister Agnès Pannier-Runacher outlines in an interview the government's vision of the trajectory that would enable France to gradually reduce its dependence on fossil fuels.

title: WHO asks China for more data on respiratory illness
summary: On Wednesday, the UN health body urged people in China to 'follow measures to reduce the risk of respiratory illness' and asked authorities for more information about a reported spike in cases among children.

title: Israel says truce and Gaza hostage release postponed until at least Friday
summary: The delay announced on Thursday is a hammer blow to families desperate to see their loved ones return home and to two million-plus Gazans praying for an end to 47 days of war and deprivation.

title: In Tel Aviv, the hostage families's hopes and fears as they await the first releases
summary: The head of Israel's National Security Council said that the releases would not take place 'before Friday' and that negotiations were 'advancing and continuing constantly.'

title: Far-right Geert Wilders triumphs in dramatic Dutch election but could struggle to form coalition
summary: Wilders' Party for Freedom is expected to win 35 of the 150 seats in the Second Chamber, according to exit polls. In order to govern, it will have to reach an agreement with right-wing and center-right parties.

title: 'I miss Nagorno-Karabakh so much': The new life of refugees in Armenia
summary: The 100,000 inhabitants of the former separatist enclave are still in shock as they try to rebuild their lives after losing their territory to Azerbaijan in September.

title: Gordon Brown, former British PM: 'COP28 will go down in history – either as a pivotal moment or as a missed opportunity'
summary: The UN's special envoy for global education believes that France, with its experience of reaching the Paris agreement, could play a pivotal role at the climate conference in Dubai from November 30 to December 12.
